data.title: Euro 2024 tickets: How to buy them, how much they cost and sale dates
data.meta_description:

data.text:
The 2024 European Championship takes place in Germany between June 14 and July 14.

The qualifiers started in March and conclude in November before March’s play-offs to determine the final 24 competing teams.

There was record ticket demand for Euro 2020, with the tournament attracting 28.3million ticket requests, and next summer’s tournament has proved to be similarly popular.

This is not without its controversy, with supporter disappointment at missing out on tickets during the first round of balloting compounded by tickets then swiftly appearing on resale sites for substantially inflated prices.

The Athletic has the lowdown on the Euro 2024 ticketing situation.

When Euro 2024 tickets go on sale and how to buy them

Over 1.2million tickets were made available in the first round of Euro 2024 ticket applications, which ran from October 3 to October 26 2023. Tickets were allocated via a UEFA portal lottery process. Applicants could apply for a maximum of four tickets per match and individuals were not awarded tickets for different matches scheduled for the same day. Applicants applied for a total average of 13 tickets. Successful applicants were informed on November 14.

Those who were unsuccessful in their applications in the initial draw have been automatically entered in UEFA’s “Fans First” programme and will be alerted to new ticket availability from the first lottery phase.

The second ticket ballot will open after the tournament draw on December 2 2023. One million tickets will be available to supporters from the 21 qualified nations. Supporters will apply for tickets via their national association before making their purchase through UEFA’s website. These will typically be allocated to members of national associations’ supporter groups and be distributed using a loyalty points based system.

Details of where to apply via each national association can be found at https://www.uefa.com/euro2024/ticketing/

Tickets will also be held back for supporters of the three nations that qualify through the Euro 2024 play-offs — three from Poland, Estonia, Wales, Finland, Israel, Iceland, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Ukraine, Georgia, Luxembourg, Greece and Kazakhstan. The play-offs take place on March 21 and March 26 2024.

UEFA will open a ticket resale platform in spring 2024. This will enable fans to purchase unwanted tickets at resale value and is part of UEFA’s attempts to combat fraudulent ticket sales.

Is the process different to previous tournaments?

At previous tournaments, supporters would register for tickets directly via UEFA’s website, even after the group stage draw. The allocation process was still conducted in collaboration with national associations.

Supporters applying for Euro 2024 tickets via the second ticket ballot, which takes place after the group stage draw, instead register through their national association.

How much do Euro 2024 tickets cost?

The cheapest tickets available for Euro 2024 are €30 (£26.24, $32.63) for the lowest category pricing of group stage fixtures. A total of 270,000 tickets are priced at €30.

All group stage tickets range from €30 to €200 (£174.91, $217) apart from the opening game at Bayern Munich’s Munich Football Arena, where tickets range from €50 (£42.73, $54.39) to €600 (£524.79, $652.64).

Tickets for the knockout stages range from €50 for the cheapest round of 16 fixture to €600 for the most expensive category 1 semi-final ticket.

Prices for the final, which takes place at Berlin’s Olympiastadion, range from €90 (£78.71, $97.90) to €1,000 (£874.58, $1,087.73).

Have there been any problems?

Given demand, a number of supporters missed out on tickets in the initial ballot. UEFA confirmed it received over 20million “genuine” ticket requests for the first round of sales, where over 1.2million tickets were made available. Over 2.2million tickets were requested for the final — 33 times the size of the Olympiastadion’s 74,000 capacity.

Tickets have since appeared on resale websites for heavily inflated prices. One platform claimed to have 20 tickets for the final priced at £43,500-per-ticket — 49 times their face value. The resale or advertisement of resale of tickets is strictly prohibited by UEFA.

UEFA did identify bots during the ticketing request process but claim to have taken them out of the lottery. The use of bots, or any computer software to increase a user’s chance of their application being successful, is a breach of UEFA’s ticketing terms and conditions.

What are the fixtures?

Group stage

Friday, June 14

Germany vs Scotland (Munich, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Saturday, June 15

Hungary vs Switzerland (Cologne, 3pm CEST, 2pm BST, 9am ET)

Spain vs Croatia (Berlin, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Italy vs Albania (Dortmund, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Sunday, June 16

Play-off Winner A vs Netherlands (Hamburg, 3pm CEST, 2pm BST, 9am ET)

Slovenia vs Denmark (Stuttgart, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Serbia vs England (Gelsenkirchen, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Monday, June 17

Romania vs Play-off Winner B (Munich, 3pm CEST, 2pm BST, 9am ET)

Belgium vs Slovakia (Frankfurt, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Austria vs France (Dusseldorf, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET))

Tuesday, June 18

Turkey vs Play-off Winner C (Dortmund, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Portugal vs Czech Republic (Leipzig, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Wednesday, June 19

Croatia vs Albania (Hamburg, 3pm CEST, 2pm BST, 9am ET)

Germany vs Hungary (Stuttgart, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Scotland vs Switzerland (Cologne, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Thursday, June 20

Slovenia vs Serbia (Munich, 3pm CEST, 2pm BST, 9am ET)

Denmark vs England (Frankfurt, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Spain vs Italy (Gelsenkirchen, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Friday, June 21

Slovakia vs Play-off Winner B (Dusseldorf, 3pm CEST, 2pm BST, 9am ET)

Play-off Winner A vs Austria (Berlin, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Netherlands vs France (Leipzig, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Saturday, June 22

Play-off Winner C vs Czech Republic (Hamburg, 3pm CEST, 2pm BST, 9am ET)

Turkey vs Portugal (Dortmund, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Belgium vs Romania (Cologne, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Sunday, June 23

Switzerland vs Germany (Frankfurt, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Scotland vs Hungary (Stuttgart, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Monday, June 24

Croatia vs Italy (Leipzig, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Albania vs Spain (Dusseldorf, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Tuesday, June 25

Netherlands vs Austria (Berlin, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

France vs Play-off Winner A (Dortmund, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

England vs Slovenia (Cologne, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Denmark vs Serbia (Munich, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Wednesday, June 26

Slovakia vs Romania (Frankfurt, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Play-off Winner B vs Belgium (Stuttgart, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Czech Republic vs Turkey (Hamburg, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Play-off Winner C vs Portugal (Gelsenkirchen, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Round of 16

Saturday, June 29

Match 38 2A vs 2B (Berlin, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Match 37 1A vs 2C (Dortmund, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Sunday, June 30

Match 40 1C vs 3D/E/F (Gelsenkirchen, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Match 39 1B vs 3A/D/E/F (Cologne, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Monday, July 1

Match 42 2D vs 2E (Dusseldorf, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Match 41 1F vs 3A/B/C (Frankfurt, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Tuesday, July 2

Match 43 1E vs 3A/B/C/D (Munich, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Match 44 1D vs 2F (Leipzig, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Quarter-finals

Friday, July 5

Match 45 W39 vs W37 (Stuttgart, 6pm CEST, 5pm BST, 12pm ET)

Match 46 W41 vs W42 (Hamburg, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)

Saturday, 6 July

Wednesday, July 10

Final

Sunday, July 14

Match 51 W49 vs W50 (Berlin, 9pm CEST, 8pm BST, 3pm ET)
